rev.comment: /* Censorship in mainland China */ -NPOV per official political NPOV policy on Wikipedia.
rev.diff:
Line 161: Line 161:
[[Image:Google-censorship-slips.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Two "sensitive" images slip through the net on Page 5 of the Image Search results of "Tiananmen" on Google China (February 15, 2006)]]
[[Image:Google-censorship-slips.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Two "sensitive" images slip through the net on Page 5 of the Image Search results of "Tiananmen" on Google China (February 15, 2006)]]
â
The [[People's Republic of China]], whose [[human rights in the People's Republic of China|human rights record]] has been widely criticized by the international community, has in the past [[Internet censorship in mainland China|restricted citizen access]] to popular search engines such as [[Altavista]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[Google (search engine)|Google]]. The mirror search site [[elgooG]] has been used by Chinese citizens to get around blocked content. This complete ban is currently lifted. However, the government remains active in filtering Internet content. In October 2005, Blogger and access to the Google Cache were made available in China; however, in December 2005, some Chinese users of Blogger reported that their access to the site was once again restricted.
+
The [[People's Republic of China]] (PRC), whose [[human rights in the People's Republic of China|human rights record]] has been widely criticized by the international community, has in the past [[Internet censorship in mainland China|restricted citizen access]] to popular search engines such as [[Altavista]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[Google (search engine)|Google]]. The mirror search site [[elgooG]] has been used by its citizens in [[mainland China]] to get around blocked content. This complete ban is currently lifted. However, the government remains active in filtering Internet content. In October 2005, Blogger and access to the Google Cache were made available in mainland China; however, in December 2005, some mainland Chinese users of Blogger reported that their access to the site was once again restricted.
â
In January 2006 Google affirmed its intent to filter certain keywords given to it by the Chinese government. The restrictions will apply to thousands of terms and websites.[http://www.breitbart.com/news/2006/01/24/D8FBCF686.html] The censored content will appear on a website called google.cn. Google was heavily criticized for the move, yet it claims it is necessary to keep the Chinese government from blocking Google entirely. The company does not plan to give the government information about the users who search for blocked content, and will inform users of restricted categories. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4647398.stm] Google states on its help pages that it does not censor content, but it does block pages as demanded for in certain jurisdictions, such as [[DMCA]] requests in the United States.
+
In January 2006 Google affirmed its intent to filter certain keywords given to it by the government of the PRC. The restrictions will apply to thousands of terms and websites.[http://www.breitbart.com/news/2006/01/24/D8FBCF686.html] The censored content will appear on a website called google.cn. Google was heavily criticized for the move, yet it claims it is necessary to keep the PRC government from blocking Google entirely. The company does not plan to give the government information about the users who search for blocked content, and will inform users of restricted categories. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4647398.stm] Google states on its help pages that it does not censor content, but it does block pages as demanded for in certain jurisdictions, such as [[DMCA]] requests in the United States.
Most Chinese Internet users did not express much concern about Google's choice, with one blogger saying that censorship is a fact of life in China and Google could not have done any better.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/4650158.stm] Also, Google offers to Chinese internet users a choice that protects their privacy better than existing search engines available in China, since Google keeps confidential records of its users outside China, unlike domestic search engines that could be compelled by the government to hand over information at any time. [http://money.cnn.com/2006/02/15/news/international/pluggedin_fortune/index.htm?cnn=yes] The following message appears at the bottom of the Google search result page whenever results are blocked: æ®å½å°æ³å¾æ³è§åæ¿ç­ï¼é¨åæç´¢ç»ææªäºæ¾ç¤ºã (''In accordance with local laws and policies, some of the results have not been displayed.'') Currently, Google is the only major China-based search engine to explicitly inform the user when search results are blocked or hidden.
Most Chinese Internet users did not express much concern about Google's choice, with one blogger saying that censorship is a fact of life in China and Google could not have done any better.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/4650158.stm] Also, Google offers to Chinese internet users a choice that protects their privacy better than existing search engines available in China, since Google keeps confidential records of its users outside China, unlike domestic search engines that could be compelled by the government to hand over information at any time. [http://money.cnn.com/2006/02/15/news/international/pluggedin_fortune/index.htm?cnn=yes] The following message appears at the bottom of the Google search result page whenever results are blocked: æ®å½å°æ³å¾æ³è§åæ¿ç­ï¼é¨åæç´¢ç»ææªäºæ¾ç¤ºã (''In accordance with local laws and policies, some of the results have not been displayed.'') Currently, Google is the only major China-based search engine to explicitly inform the user when search results are blocked or hidden.
